content.title: Mesenteric Venous Thrombosis
content.definition: Thrombosis of the mesenteric venous system (SMV, IMV, portal vein) causing intestinal congestion, ischemia, and potentially infarction. Represents 5-15% of acute mesenteric ischemia cases with a distinct pathophysiology and better prognosis than arterial causes.

symptoms: Abdominal pain (often insidious onset over days to weeks)

classification.acute_mvt: Symptoms < 4 weeks, highest risk of intestinal infarction
classification.subacute_mvt: Symptoms 4-12 weeks, collateral formation may occur

hypercoagulable_states: Protein C, S, or antithrombin deficiency

imaging.target_sign: Enhancing bowel wall around low-density center

laboratory.hypercoagulable_workup: Indicated in all cases without clear provoking factor

anticoagulation.long_term: Warfarin or DOAC for 3-6 months minimum
anticoagulation.indefinite: If underlying hypercoagulable state or recurrent

management.second_look_laparotomy: Consider if borderline bowel viability at initial surgery

codes.icd_10: K55.0 | Acute vascular disorders of intestine

clinical_pearls: MVT has more insidious onset than arterial mesenteric ischemia - pain out of proportion to exam is less dramatic
Always order hypercoagulable workup - up to 80% have identifiable prothrombotic condition
JAK2 mutation testing important - may reveal occult myeloproliferative neoplasm
CT with IV contrast is diagnostic - look for portal/SMV filling defects
Anticoagulation alone sufficient in most cases without bowel infarction
learning_objectives: Distinguish MVT from arterial mesenteric ischemia by presentation timing
Identify CT findings diagnostic of MVT
Understand indications for surgery vs anticoagulation
Know when to order hypercoagulable workup
board_review_points: MVT = most insidious onset of mesenteric ischemia types
Factor V Leiden = most common inherited cause
JAK2 mutation should be checked in all unexplained MVT
